ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I would highly recommend this course to other students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Practical experience and visual learning
I enjoyed visiting different parts of Connecticut and meeting industry folks.
The fuel cell trip
Very interesting course that gets students thinking about practical applications of industrial ecology.
The diversity of the places we visited.
Visits to companies of different scale and categories which gave a wider view of industry practices.

The opportunity to see industrial operations in action and to speak with managers and workers who are trying to confront environmental concerns in their everyday work is invaluable. You can't get the kind of in-depth attention to detail in any other course at FES and to see a variety of factories, warehouses, etc. gives you a diverse set of experiences to apply your ideas and knowledge to.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Expectations for length of the field trips should just be set to 8-2pm, to avoid schedule conflicts.
The readings could have been a bit more focused and there didn't seem to be much of a point to the process flow charts since we didn't really get any meaningful feedback.
It might help to add more trips to the class.
A couple of trips may be added if time permits.

A set pattern could be followed for all the visits: Before leaving for the site visit, Instructor should lead a 15 minutes discussion on the reading and what aspects to specifically focus on during the visit and how those aspects relate to the professional skills students are looking to acquire. After reaching, a presentation by the company representatives where the whole process is explained, so that in field even if not audible, students will still know the process. A 10 minutes discussion after reaching back to campus on the learning from Site visit.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The one initial class lecture gave some good insight to how we should structure our work for the rest of the semester, but it was not as complete as it could have been. Half-way through the semester, we should have been able to get feedback on our specific process flow diagrams, and review recommendations we made to facilities.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It gave me a practical idea of what industrial operations are. Very useful in terms of some practical background.
I am interested in practical applications of industrial ecology, so this class is perfect! I'd like to be a consultant who can identify cost savings while highlighting environmental benefit.
I'm studying Industrial Environmental Management so this course provides a great real world classroom to learn in.
It was very useful for me to see how an industrial operation works in the ground.
To learn best industry practices in the U.S. is one of my goals of coming for this masters program. This course meets it perfect through field visits and viewing things live.
I am interested in sustainable business and industrial ecology and wanted to get some more on the ground experiences with some of the concepts.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I wanted to have a real idea of what happens on the field.
To gain practical experience and a knowledge of the state of manufacturing in the Northeast
Heard great things and it sounded very interesting.
I don't come from a business or an industrial background. I wanted to see how operations run on the ground.
To learn the current environment and sustainability related industry practices in the U.S.
I have heard great things about it and wanted to get some real-world examples to complement my classroom learning in sustainable operations.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I think they will be very useful in the future.
Yes
Yes
Yes. We visited corporations across different sectors which was very helpful.
I thought I learned even more than I expected.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Valuable knowledge.
Read about the company and sketch an initial process flow diagram for the processes that may occur, before attending the field trip. This will check for understanding.
Take it. It's worth getting up at 730 on a Friday.
Keep a good chunk of time free for the field trip days.
Attend all field trips. Dont miss any.

Prepare for the field trips so that you at least have some idea of what to expect. The tours vary significantly in style and content so if you go into a site expecting it to be similar to one of the prior weeks you are probably wrong. It helps immensely to be prepared because then you can take in the maximum information and you also know what questions are important to ask.
